title: List of cognitive biases (Wikipedia article)
introSummary: Cognitive biases are systematic patterns of deviation from norm or rationality in judgment, often studied in psychology, sociology, and behavioral economics.

biases.name: Anchoring bias
biases.summary: Tendency to rely too heavily on the first piece of information (the 'anchor') when making decisions.

subBiases.name: Common source bias
subBiases.summary: Tendency to compare or rely on studies from the same source or methodology.

subBiases.name: Conservatism bias
subBiases.summary: Failing to revise one’s beliefs adequately when presented with new evidence.

subBiases.name: Functional fixedness
subBiases.summary: Seeing objects as only functioning in their usual way.

subBiases.name: Law of the instrument
subBiases.summary: "If all you have is a hammer, everything looks like a nail." Over-reliance on a familiar tool.

biases.name: Apophenia
biases.summary: Perceiving meaningful connections among unrelated phenomena.

subBiases.name: Clustering illusion
subBiases.summary: Overestimating importance of small clusters or streaks in large samples of random data.

subBiases.name: Illusory correlation
subBiases.summary: Seeing a relationship between two unrelated events.

subBiases.name: Pareidolia
subBiases.summary: Seeing significant patterns in vague stimuli (e.g., seeing faces in clouds).

biases.name: Availability heuristic
biases.summary: Overestimating likelihood of events that come easily to mind, e.g., because they’re recent or vivid.

subBiases.name: Anthropocentric thinking
subBiases.summary: Using human analogies to reason about less familiar phenomena.

subBiases.name: Anthropomorphism
subBiases.summary: Attributing human traits or intentions to non-humans (animals, objects, etc.).

subBiases.name: Attentional bias
subBiases.summary: Recurring thoughts affect perception, focusing attention on certain stimuli.

subBiases.name: Frequency illusion / Baader–Meinhof phenomenon
subBiases.summary: Once you notice something, you see it everywhere.

subBiases.name: Implicit association
subBiases.summary: Automatic and unconscious association between concepts.

subBiases.name: Salience bias
subBiases.summary: Focusing on items that are more striking and ignoring those that are not.

subBiases.name: Selection bias
subBiases.summary: Non-random sample selection leads to unrepresentative data.

subBiases.name: Survivorship bias
subBiases.summary: Concentrating on the survivors of a process and overlooking those that did not survive.

subBiases.name: Well travelled road effect
subBiases.summary: Underestimating travel time for familiar routes and overestimating it for unfamiliar routes.

biases.name: Cognitive dissonance
biases.summary: Mental discomfort caused by holding contradictory information or beliefs.

subBiases.name: Normalcy bias
subBiases.summary: Refusal to plan for or react to a disaster which has never happened before.

subBiases.name: Effort justification
subBiases.summary: Attributing greater value to an outcome if one worked hard for it (e.g. IKEA effect).

subBiases.name: Ben Franklin effect
subBiases.summary: Doing a favor for someone makes you like them more.

biases.name: Confirmation bias
biases.summary: Seeking or interpreting evidence in a way that confirms existing beliefs.

subBiases.name: Backfire effect
subBiases.summary: Disconfirming evidence can strengthen existing beliefs.

subBiases.name: Congruence bias
subBiases.summary: Testing only direct confirmations of one hypothesis instead of seeking alternatives.

subBiases.name: Experimenter's / Expectation bias
subBiases.summary: Researchers more readily accept data that fits their expectations.

subBiases.name: Observer-expectancy effect
subBiases.summary: Unconsciously influencing an experiment to find expected results.

subBiases.name: Selective perception
subBiases.summary: Expectations shape what we perceive.

subBiases.name: Semmelweis reflex
subBiases.summary: Rejecting new evidence that contradicts established norms.

biases.name: Egocentric bias
biases.summary: Overreliance on one’s own perspective; seeing oneself differently from how others see you.

subBiases.name: Bias blind spot
subBiases.summary: Seeing oneself as less biased than other people.

subBiases.name: False consensus effect
subBiases.summary: Overestimating how many people share your beliefs or opinions.

subBiases.name: False uniqueness bias
subBiases.summary: Believing one's attributes or traits are more unique than they really are.

subBiases.name: Forer (Barnum) effect
subBiases.summary: Accepting vague, general statements as being highly accurate for oneself (e.g., horoscopes).

subBiases.name: Illusion of asymmetric insight
subBiases.summary: Thinking you know others better than they know you.

subBiases.name: Illusion of control
subBiases.summary: Overestimating how much control one has over external events.

subBiases.name: Illusion of transparency
subBiases.summary: Overestimating how well others can discern your internal states and vice versa.

subBiases.name: Illusion of validity
subBiases.summary: Overestimating the accuracy of one’s judgments.

subBiases.name: Illusory superiority (Lake Wobegon effect)
subBiases.summary: Overestimating one’s positive qualities compared to others.

subBiases.name: Naïve cynicism
subBiases.summary: Expecting others to be more self-serving and biased than oneself.

subBiases.name: Naïve realism
subBiases.summary: Belief that we see objective reality and anyone who disagrees is irrational or uninformed.

subBiases.name: Overconfidence effect
subBiases.summary: Excessive confidence in one’s answers to questions or estimates.

subBiases.name: Planning fallacy
subBiases.summary: Underestimating how long it will take to complete tasks.

subBiases.name: Restraint bias
subBiases.summary: Overestimating one’s capacity to resist temptation.

subBiases.name: Trait ascription bias
subBiases.summary: Seeing oneself as more flexible and less predictable than others.

subBiases.name: Third-person effect
subBiases.summary: Believing that media messages affect others more than oneself.

biases.name: Extension neglect
biases.summary: Failing to properly consider sample size or scope when evaluating outcomes or probabilities.

subBiases.name: Base rate fallacy / Base rate neglect
subBiases.summary: Ignoring general base-rate information and focusing on specifics.

subBiases.name: Compassion fade
subBiases.summary: Less compassion for large groups than for a single identifiable victim.

subBiases.name: Conjunction fallacy
subBiases.summary: Assuming specific conditions are more probable than broader ones.

subBiases.name: Duration neglect
subBiases.summary: Overlooking the length of an experience when evaluating its impact.

subBiases.name: Hyperbolic discounting
subBiases.summary: Stronger preference for immediate payoffs relative to later payoffs.

subBiases.name: Insensitivity to sample size
subBiases.summary: Underestimating variability in small samples.

subBiases.name: Less-is-better effect
subBiases.summary: Preferring the smaller set if judged independently, but not in comparison.

subBiases.name: Neglect of probability
subBiases.summary: Ignoring probability in uncertain situations.

subBiases.name: Scope neglect
subBiases.summary: Insensitivity to the scope of a problem (e.g., paying the same to save 2,000 or 20,000 birds).

subBiases.name: Zero-risk bias
subBiases.summary: Preferring to reduce a small risk to zero over a greater total reduction in a larger risk.

biases.name: False priors
biases.summary: Incorrect initial assumptions or knowledge leading to biased conclusions.

subBiases.name: Agent detection bias
subBiases.summary: Presuming the intervention of a sentient agent in ambiguous situations.

subBiases.name: Automation bias
subBiases.summary: Overreliance on automated systems, overriding correct decisions.

subBiases.name: Gender bias
subBiases.summary: Implicit biases that discriminate based on gender.

subBiases.name: Sexual overperception bias
subBiases.summary: Overestimating or underestimating another's sexual interest.

subBiases.name: Stereotyping
subBiases.summary: Expecting certain characteristics based on group membership.

biases.name: Framing effect
biases.summary: Drawing different conclusions from the same information, depending on how it's presented.

subBiases.name: Contrast effect
subBiases.summary: Enhancement or diminishment of perception when compared with something else.

subBiases.name: Decoy effect
subBiases.summary: Preferences change when a dominated option is introduced as a 'decoy.'

subBiases.name: Default effect
subBiases.summary: Choosing the default option when faced with multiple choices.

subBiases.name: Denomination effect
subBiases.summary: Spending more when money is in smaller denominations.

subBiases.name: Distinction bias
subBiases.summary: Seeing options as more dissimilar when evaluated together than separately.

subBiases.name: Domain neglect bias / Context neglect bias
subBiases.summary: Failing to apply relevant domain knowledge or context properly.

biases.name: Logical fallacy (selected)
biases.summary: Errors in reasoning often arising from incorrect inferences or assumptions.

subBiases.name: Berkson's paradox
subBiases.summary: Misinterpreting conditional probabilities in statistical contexts.

subBiases.name: Escalation of commitment / Sunk cost fallacy
subBiases.summary: Continuing a failing course of action because of prior investment.

subBiases.name: Gambler's fallacy
subBiases.summary: Believing that separate chance events influence one another (e.g., coin flips).

subBiases.name: Hot-hand fallacy
subBiases.summary: Belief that success 'streaks' increase the probability of subsequent success.

subBiases.name: Plan continuation bias
subBiases.summary: Sticking to an initial plan despite evidence it’s no longer appropriate.

subBiases.name: Subadditivity effect
subBiases.summary: Judging the probability of the whole as less than the sum of its parts.

subBiases.name: Zero-sum bias
subBiases.summary: Mistakenly viewing a situation as strictly win–lose.

biases.name: Prospect theory biases
biases.summary: Behavioral economic theory describing how people choose between probabilistic alternatives.

subBiases.name: Ambiguity effect
subBiases.summary: Avoiding choices where probability of outcomes is unknown.

subBiases.name: Disposition effect
subBiases.summary: Selling assets that have gained value, while keeping assets that have lost value.

subBiases.name: Dread aversion
subBiases.summary: Negative anticipation can have disproportionately strong emotional impact.

subBiases.name: Endowment effect
subBiases.summary: Demanding more to give up an object than one would pay to acquire it.

subBiases.name: Loss aversion
subBiases.summary: Losses loom larger than gains of the same size.

subBiases.name: Pseudocertainty effect
subBiases.summary: Risk-averse choices when outcomes are positive, but risk-seeking to avoid negative outcomes.

subBiases.name: Status quo bias
subBiases.summary: Preference for the current state of affairs.

subBiases.name: System justification
subBiases.summary: Defending the status quo, even at one’s own expense.

biases.name: Self-assessment biases
biases.summary: Biases affecting how people judge their own abilities or traits.

subBiases.name: Dunning–Kruger effect
subBiases.summary: Unskilled people often overestimate their competence; experts sometimes underestimate theirs.

subBiases.name: Hot-cold empathy gap
subBiases.summary: Underestimating how states of drive or emotion alter behavior or preferences.

subBiases.name: Hard–easy effect
subBiases.summary: Overestimating chances of success on hard tasks, underestimating for easy ones.

subBiases.name: Illusion of explanatory depth
subBiases.summary: Believing one understands complex topics better than one actually does.

subBiases.name: Impostor syndrome
subBiases.summary: Persistent fear of being exposed as a fraud despite evidence of success.

subBiases.name: Objectivity illusion
subBiases.summary: Believing oneself to be more objective than others.

biases.name: Truth judgment biases
biases.summary: Biases that affect how people judge the truth or believability of statements.

subBiases.name: Belief bias
subBiases.summary: Judging the strength of an argument by the believability of its conclusion.

subBiases.name: Illusory truth effect
subBiases.summary: Repeated statements feel truer than new statements, regardless of their truth value.

subBiases.name: Rhyme as reason effect
subBiases.summary: Rhyming statements are seen as more truthful or persuasive.

subBiases.name: Subjective validation
subBiases.summary: Statements are seen as true if one’s belief demands it to be true.

biases.name: Other biases (selected)
biases.summary: Miscellaneous biases affecting decisions or behavior.

examples.name: Action bias
examples.summary: Preference to act to address a problem, even when doing nothing is better.

examples.name: Additive bias
examples.summary: Inclination to add elements to solve a problem rather than remove them.

examples.name: Curse of knowledge
examples.summary: Difficulty in imagining what it’s like not to know something once you do know it.

examples.name: Declinism
examples.summary: Viewing the past favorably and the future negatively.

examples.name: End-of-history illusion
examples.summary: Belief that one will change less in the future than one has in the past.

examples.name: Hindsight bias
examples.summary: "I knew it all along." Seeing past events as more predictable than they were.

examples.name: Optimism bias
examples.summary: Overestimating the likelihood of positive events and underestimating negative ones.

examples.name: Outcome bias
examples.summary: Judging decisions by their outcomes rather than by their quality at the time.

examples.name: Pessimism bias
examples.summary: Overestimating the likelihood of negative outcomes, often seen with depression.

examples.name: Projection bias
examples.summary: Overestimating how much future preferences will match current preferences.

examples.name: Proportionality bias
examples.summary: Assuming large events have large causes; can fuel conspiracy thinking.

examples.name: Surrogation
examples.summary: Confusing a performance measure with the actual construct it represents.

examples.name: Teleological bias
examples.summary: Ascribing purpose or design to natural events that are not goal-directed.

examples.name: Unconscious / Implicit bias
examples.summary: Automatic attitudes or stereotypes that affect understanding and actions.

examples.name: Unit bias
examples.summary: Perception that a single unit (e.g., one plate of food) is the ‘appropriate’ amount.

examples.name: Women are wonderful effect
examples.summary: Associating more positive attributes with women than men.

sections.summary: Biases affecting the encoding, storage, or retrieval of memories.

subsections.summary: Mistakenly attributing a memory to an incorrect source.

subBiases.name: Cryptomnesia
subBiases.summary: A memory is mistaken for original thought.

subBiases.name: False memory
subBiases.summary: Imagined events mistaken for true memories.

subBiases.name: Social cryptomnesia
subBiases.summary: Forgetting how social change occurred while remembering that it happened.

subBiases.name: Source confusion
subBiases.summary: Mixing up the source of a memory.

subBiases.name: Suggestibility
subBiases.summary: Memories influenced by the phrasing of questions or external suggestions.

subBiases.name: Perky effect
subBiases.summary: Real images can be misremembered as imagined and vice versa.

biasList.name: Bizarreness effect
biasList.summary: Bizarre information is more memorable than commonplace information.

biasList.name: Choice-supportive bias
biasList.summary: Remembering one's choices as better than they were.

biasList.name: Consistency bias
biasList.summary: Incorrectly remembering past beliefs as similar to present beliefs.

biasList.name: Fading affect bias
biasList.summary: Emotion associated with unpleasant memories fades faster than that of pleasant ones.

biasList.name: Google effect
biasList.summary: Forgetting information that can easily be found online.

biasList.name: Hindsight bias
biasList.summary: Recalling past events as more predictable than they actually were.

biasList.name: Misinformation effect
biasList.summary: Memory becomes distorted by post-event information.

biasList.name: Negativity bias (in memory)
biasList.summary: Greater recall of unpleasant memories over positive ones.

biasList.name: Peak–end rule
biasList.summary: Evaluating experiences by how they were at their peak and how they ended.

biasList.name: Rosy retrospection
biasList.summary: Recalling past events more favorably than they actually were.

biasList.name: Spacing effect
biasList.summary: Better recall for information studied in spaced intervals.

biasList.name: Zeigarnik effect
biasList.summary: Uncompleted tasks are remembered better than completed ones.

seeAlso: Heuristics in judgment and decision making
notes: This JSON is an illustrative example, providing a condensed summary of each bias.
